title: House of Lords shame as peers STILL clocking-in amid fresh calls to axe the upper house
text:
Get politics   Thank you for subscribing!   
There are fresh calls to scrap the House of Lords after it was revealed peers still have their noses in the trough, nearly four years after the Mirror exposed the clocking-in scandal . 
One told how she saw members ­nipping in to claim their £300 attendance fee ­without staying for debates or votes. 
Former Lords Speaker Baroness D’Souza told how a peer left a taxi waiting outside ­Parliament while he went inside to register for his daily allowance. 
Her comments came in an ­explosive TV documentary on the House which also featured lords showing off their country ­mansions, sipping champagne and whining about the loss of perks such as a TV room where they watched the races. 
Exposing the new clocking-in scandal, Baroness D’Souza said: “I was leaving the House quite late and there was a peer, who shall be utterly nameless, who jumped out of a taxi just outside the peers’ entrance, left the engine running. Read More Scottish pile Lord Palemer inherited (Photo: alamy) There are fresh calls to scrap the House of Lords (Photo: AFP) 
“He ran in, presumably to show he’d ­attended, and then ran out again while the taxi was still running. That’s not normal, but it is something that does happen.” 
Baroness D’Souza claimed the lord was one of “many, many, many who contribute absolutely nothing, but who claim the full allowance”. 
The Electoral Reform Society is leading calls to reform the House of Lords, which was described by one peer as London’s best “elderly care home”. 
Chief ­executive Katie Ghose said: “This provides more evidence that we urgently need to move to a fully elected chamber. 
“Let’s fix this broken House before the situation gets any worse. Lord Palmer How the Daily Mirror reported the original scandal (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
“We already knew some peers claim their £300 without speaking or voting, but to hear this from the former Lords Speaker herself is astonishing and shows just how severe this problem really is. 
“Baroness D’Souza has exposed a truly scandalous situation. The public are sick to death of this kind of behaviour.” 
The new revelations come after years of Tory austerity, with ministers often branding people struggling on benefits as the ­“something for nothing” society. 
And it follows the Mirror’s 2013 report on the clocking-in scandal involving ­disgraced former Tory peer Lord ­Haningfield. 
We caught the expenses cheat repeatedly popping into ­Parliament for barely half an hour at a time to secure his daily payment of £300. Whistleblower Baroness D'Souza Luxury bannisters in Lord Palmer's mansion 
For or 11 of the 19 days we followed him he spent less than 40 minutes each time inside the chamber. 
Police pressed charges but they were dropped last year after Parliament ­ intervened at the 11th hour. 
The new BBC documentary, Inside the Lords, also features Lord Palmer showing off the solid silver banisters of the ­staircase at his £400million ­Scottish mansion, which he inherited with his seat. 
He said: “As far as we know this is the only silver staircase in the world.” 
The peer reveals one pal took 40 years to make his first speech in the Lords and told of another’s lunchtime boozing.
